instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message:
Hey guys,

Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Macbook Pro here with some frustrating issues. We get a green light on the AC adapter however, no fanspin/chime, and the CPU and GPU start to get hot (could be due to lack of fan spin?)

Checked all of the voltages, the only outlier is <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_T29BST</SIGNAL>, which is 2.82V. (see attached image for all voltages)

From this I checked <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR> as this seem to be where it's made, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is a steady 12.6V and the gaet for <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR> is 12.2V. At the drain of <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR> however, the voltage is a meager 0.3V. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR> to no effect.

Diode mode to ground at drain of <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR> is 0.4V (only works with negative on component, positive on ground? I've not noticed this with other components when diode checking, or maybe I'm going mad), resistance is 100kohmn (slowly goes down),

Consequentially, <SIGNAL>PP15V_T29</SIGNAL> is 0.32V

Plus, I am going to assume that <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is supposed to be 5V given the name, my schematic shows 3.3V however so for consistency, I still put 3.3V.

Help would be appreciated!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Ok so do you get a light on a USB mouse when you plug it in?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Didn't expect that question! But, yes it does power USB devices it seems

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Ok plug in a known good LCD and see if you get anything on the screen. Shine a flashlight through the Apple logo to see if you get a blinking questionmark folder. Also seems like you got a bad fan.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Definitely not a bad fan, replaced the fan and still having the same issue. I don't have a spare screen to hand so cannot test, however there is no question mark folder when shining a light through. Also as I said, there is no chime. If the display was just not working, there would still be a chime

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message:
It powers a USB device....it was asked if a USB mouse would light up the LED. 

As there is not fan spin <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is probably not present. Check all power rails for the missing one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Will test VCore shortly, but yea duke as said above, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_T29BST</SIGNAL> is 2.8V where it should be 12.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: You are measuring Thunderbolt voltages which have nothing to do with the board booting or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message:
Apologies duke, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_T29BST</SIGNAL> was in the "always present" set so I assumed it should be there. Just checked all CPU Vcore voltages and I got the following:

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>                  1.16v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>                    0
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL>         1.5
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL>     1.06
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL>   1.79


I did just test with another mouse and it's a bit odd, the light for the mouse (as in the back light for the scroll wheel, not the laser) flicks on when plugging into power but turns off after a split second. The laser light doesn't come on at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message:
Vcore is present at 1.16V so there must be fan spin. But the 1.16V would indicate it is brain dead as normally it will drop down from 1.16 to under 1V.

Any history on this board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: History is liquid damage, had wine spilled on it and the customer used it until it died - only lasted for a day. Not even moderate signs of liquid damage to be seen, there are a few dirty pads but I've cleaned them up and they have good connections.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Board is brain dead and it could be anything. Give the board a good clean first if no real corrosion is evident. Crap under the SMC is very likely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Will remove the SMC and see if there is any crud, hopefully none has gone under the CPU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Dont, just some flux and heat first to try and clear the crap. Ultrasoniced the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message:
Absolutely immaculate under there! Not a pinch of crud. Have reballed/resoldered every component on the board that has a whiff of suspicion regarding it's corroded-nes. I would ultrasonic clean it, unfortunately I don't own a UC. Seems that we're getting to the end of our tether with trying to solve the issue here.

Any tips for doing a good clean without an UC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Pro - Not turning on, no fan spin, but CPU gets hot
threads.message: Have cleaned everything as best as I can, re-soldered the dodgy pads, and now we actually get a fan spin (yay). Could have either been a dodgy connection to the fan, or something completely different. Currently re-checking the voltages to see if anything has changed.
